title: ICC places Smith among game’s best ever batsmen
text:
Steve Smith registers sixth-best ICC rating in cricket history  09am by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS FOLLOWING his crucial century against India, Steve Smith has attained a career-high rating on the International Cricket Council’s official rankings that places him among the game’s greatest ever batsmen. 
With scores of 27 and 109 in the first Test against India, Smith earnt six rating points to move up to 939. 
Only five batsmen have registered a higher rating – Don Bradman (961), Len Hutton (945), Jack Hobbs (942), Ricky Ponting (942) and Peter May (941) – and Smith’s rating is the highest since Ponting climbed to 942 in 2006. 
West Indies legends Garfield Sobers, Clyde Walcott and Viv Richards, and Sri Lankan icon Kumar Sangakkara round out the top 10. They all had career-high ratings of 938. 
The highest possible rating a player can receive is 1000. 
Sitting atop the ICC’s Test batting rankings, Smith now has a 66-point buffer on second-placed Virat Kohli (873), who lost 22 points after making scores of 0 and 13 during India’s 333-run defeat. England’s Joe Root (848), New Zealand’s Kane Williamson (823) and Australia’s David Warner (805) round out the top five. 
Take a look at the stunning stats that have powered Smith to his career-high rating and how Australia’s other players fared in the latest rankings. Steve Smith has the sixth highest rating of any batsman in history. Source: AP 
BEHIND ONLY THE DON AND SUNNY 
Smith has racked up the third most runs (4888 runs at 60.34) of any player in their first 51 Tests, behind only Bradman (6996) and India’s Sunil Gavaskar (4997). 
Bradman (29) and Gavaskar (20) are also the only players to have scored more centuries in their first 51 Tests. Smith sits equal third with Matthew Hayden on 18. 
His average of 60.34 is the fourth best of any player after 51 Tests, behind Bradman (101.39), Herbert Sutcliffe (62.67) and Jack Hobbs (60.47). 
CHASING DOWN MR CRICKET AND TUBBY 
Smith’s century on Saturday drew him level with David Warner on 18 Test hundreds. The pair now sit equal 14th among Australian century makers, just behind Mark Taylor (19) and Mike Hussey (19). 
Yet to turn 28, Smith has already overtaken some of Australia’s greatest ever players, with Adam Gilchrist (17), Doug Walters (15), Ian Chappell (14) and Bill Lawry (13) all in his rear view mirror. 
ONE AWAY FROM COMPLETING THE SET 
Smith’s critics often point to his lofty average of 60.34 being the result of Australia’s batter friendly tracks. That seems a harsh criticism considering where Smith has scored his centuries. 
Smith has now scored Test hundreds in seven of the eight countries he has played in, with tons in Australia (10), England (three), India (one), New Zealand (one), South Africa (one), Sri Lanka (one) and the West Indies (one). 
The only country he has toured without scoring a century in is the United Arab Emirates, where he has a top score of 97. 
What’s more he averages above 40 in every country he has played in, with his lowest average in a nation being 41.16 in Sri Lanka. Smith puts 100 past India 0:38 
HE LOVES INDIA 
Few have enjoyed as much success against India as Smith. 
In his ninth Test against the cricketing powerhouse, the 27-year-old passed his 1000th run against India. 
And his average — which stands at 88.83 after being dismissed for 109 — is the third best of anyone to have passed the 1000-run mark against India. 
Only West Indian legend Sir Everton Weekes (1495 runs at 106.78), and Zimbabwean champion Andy Flower (1138 at 94.83) sit ahead of him. 
Some may put Smith’s dominance over India down to massive contributions on placid home wickets. 
But what can’t be denied is his more than handy average of 49.50 in India — with a century in just three Tests. 
Smith has also achieved something neither Weekes nor Flower pulled off, becoming the first player to ever score centuries in five consecutive Tests against India. 
HAZLEWOOD UP TO SECOND 
Despite only bowling nine overs during Australia’s 333-run win, Josh Hazlewood has moved up to second on the Test bowler rankings, tied with India’s Ravindra Jadeja (860). Hazlewood has never had a higher rating or better ranking. 
Unsurprisingly, Steve O’Keefe was Australia’s biggest mover on the rankings, shooting up 33 spots to 29th after his 12-wicket haul in Pune. Matt Renshaw moved up 18 spots from 52nd to 34th. Smith's lucky escapes 0:30 
India’s Ravi Ashwin remains atop the Test bowling (878) and all-rounder (448) rankings. 
Arguably the biggest surprise from the latest rankings was Mitchell Starc’s rise to fourth on the all-rounder rankings, with a career-high rating of 347. Starc is ahead of England’s Ben Stokes (327), and behind Jadeja (372) and Bangladesh’s Shakib Al Hasan (441).
